concern: Currently a 2nd year. Been getting below average scores for every midterm I've took since my freshman year. Feel like I'm way too dumb for college and I get burned out too easily. Even if I study for hours and hours, I get really bad test anxiety and can't execute the concepts I studied. I don't have any passion for any major and I'm hopeless getting into one in the first place due to my poor grades. What should I do? Drop out?

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! How's your day going? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
My day has been pretty exhausting I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed with everything going on. Yes, there are some things on my mind related to school that I'd like to discuss.
It sounds like you're feeling quite drained and have a lot on your plate. Would you like to share more about what's been going on with school that's weighing on your mind?
Yes, I'd like to share more about what's been weighing on me with school. It's been really tough dealing with the constant pressure and my struggles to keep up.

That pressure can be incredibly draining and overwhelming. It's important to acknowledge and honor those feelings. If you're comfortable, could you tell me more about what's been causing the most stress for you with school?

The main stress for me at school stems from my ongoing academic challenges and the way they affect my confidence. It's tough to handle the pressure when I feel like I'm not keeping up, even after putting in a lot of effort.

It sounds like you're putting in a lot of effort, but not seeing the results you desire, which can be incredibly disheartening. Struggling with academics can definitely impact your confidence and add to the pressure you're feeling. Have you tried any strategies to help manage this stress or improve your academic performance?

I've tried studying for extended periods and reviewing materials repeatedly to improve my performance, but it often leads to burnout and doesn't seem to help much with my test anxiety. I'm also considering ways to manage the stress better, though I'm not sure what's most effective for me right now.

Test anxiety and burnout can be significant roadblocks to academic success, even when you're putting in a lot of effort. It's great that you're open to exploring different ways to manage your stress. Have you ever tried mindfulness techniques, like deep breathing or meditation, to help calm your mind and ease anxiety?

I've tried some basic breathing exercises during study sessions, but they haven't made much of a difference in reducing my test anxiety or preventing burnout. I'm open to exploring mindfulness techniques more seriously if they might help me handle the pressure better.

Mindfulness techniques can be a great way to manage stress and anxiety, but they often require consistent practice to see results. Have you considered trying a regular meditation routine, maybe even just 510 minutes a day, to help build up your ability to stay calm and focused during stressful situations?

I've thought about starting a regular meditation routine before, but I haven't actually committed to one due to how quickly I get burned out from school pressures. I'm willing to give it a try for 510 minutes a day if it could help me feel more calm and focused during exams.

That's a great step forward! Starting with a manageable amount of time, like 510 minutes a day, can make it easier to stick with the routine and start reaping the benefits. Would you like some guidance on how to get started with a meditation practice?

Yes, I'd appreciate some guidance on starting a meditation practice, as I'm hoping it could help me manage the overwhelming feelings that come with my school challenges. I'm open to simple steps that might make it easier to incorporate into my routine without adding more stress.

Great! Here's a simple 5step guide to get you started

1. Find a quiet space where you won't be disturbed.
2. Sit comfortably, either on a chair or on the floor, with your back straight.
3. Close your eyes and focus on your breath, observing the sensations as you inhale and exhale.
4. When your mind wanders, gently bring your attention back to your breath.
5. Start with just a few minutes and gradually increase the time as you become more comfortable with the practice.

Remember, the key is consistency and patience. It might take some time to see the benefits, but stick with it and you'll likely start to notice improvements in your ability to handle stress.

Thank you for the simple guide it seems straightforward and manageable, which is exactly what I need right now. I'll give it a try to see if it helps me feel less overwhelmed during stressful school moments.

You're very welcome! I'm glad the guide seems manageable for you. Remember, the goal is to make this a helpful, stressrelieving practice, not another source of pressure. So be gentle with yourself as you begin and try not to worry if your mind wandersit's all part of the process.

I appreciate the reminder to be gentle with myselfit's easy to add pressure when I'm already feeling burned out from school demands. I'll start incorporating the meditation practice carefully to see if it helps ease my anxiety during exams.

That's a great attitude to have, especially when dealing with stress and anxiety. Being patient and kind to yourself will make it easier to stick with the practice and see the benefits over time. And remember, you're not alone in this strugglemany students experience similar challenges, and finding effective coping strategies is a process.

I appreciate you reminding me that I'm not alone in dealing with this kind of stressit's comforting to know others face similar academic challenges. I'll try to stay patient with myself as I incorporate the meditation practice, hoping it helps me manage the ongoing pressure and anxiety during exams.
